data.title: AC2024 Speakers
data.text:
Rev. Lynda Ferguson, Senior Pastor of First UMC Asheboro

Opening Worship, Friday, June 21, 2024 at 10:30am

Rev. Lynda Ferguson is an ordained elder in the Western North Carolina Conference (WNCC) of the United Methodist Church (UMC), currently serving as the Senior Pastor of First United Methodist Church in Asheboro, NC. She has served as either senior pastor or pastoral staff at several other wonderful churches in both the Western NC and North Carolina Conferences and also has worked in hospital chaplaincy and campus ministry. Rev. Ferguson currently serves as the Chair of the Board of Ordained Ministry for the WNCC. She has been a member of the Jane and Royce Reynolds Leadership Academy for Evangelism and Discipleship through the WNCC Foundation. Rev. Ferguson has been featured on PBS Religion and Ethics Newsweekly and has been a speaker for many conferences. She holds degrees from UNC-Chapel Hill (B.A.), Clemson University (M.S.), and Duke University (M.Div.). Rev. Ferguson received the coveted Athena Award by the Asheboro Chamber of Commerce in 2017. In 2019, she was honored by the Western North Carolina Conference with the Harry Denman Evangelism Award. In 2021, she was honored with the Boundless Impact Ray of Light Award for her work with inclusive communities. With The Chris Canty Foundation, she was part of the leadership team for youth empowerment through mission work in the Bahamas. She has also been involved with hunger and medical work in Nicaragua. Under her leadership, major projects to relieve human suffering have been initiated with the support of The Duke Endowment, such as the Washburn Outreach Center in Rutherford County and Lydia’s Place, a homeless shelter for women and children, in Randolph County. She serves on the Board of Directors for Wesley Community Development Corporation and the Parish Ministry Fund. She has done intentional work in racial reconciliation, LGBTQ affirmation, gender equity, and poverty relief. She comes from a long line of Methodists including her great-grandfather Francis Asbury Lindsay Clark who was a circuit rider in the mountains and foothills of North Carolina. She is the proud mom to two adult daughters, Eliza and Emily. Rev. Ferguson loves the Lord and is passionate about helping Christians grow in their discipleship, bringing others to faith in Jesus Christ, and helping others understand they are loved unconditionally by our almighty God.

Rev. Dr. Magrey DeVega, Senior Pastor at Hyde Park UMC in Tampa, FL

Bible Study Leader, Friday, June 21, 2024 at 3:45pm

The Rev. Magrey R. deVega is the Senior Pastor of Hyde Park United Methodist Church in Tampa, Florida. He is the author of thirteen books, including The Bible Year: A Journey Through Scripture in 365 Days, and Questions Jesus Asked: A Six-Week Study in the Gospels. He has a forthcoming Advent study this year titled “The Christmas Letters: Celebrating Advent with Those Who Told the Story First.” (Abingdon Press) He has been the featured speaker and preacher at conferences around the country, including the Annual Conferences of Indiana, Arkansas, Iowa, and West Ohio. He has also been a main plenary speaker at the Leadership Institute at the Church of the Resurrection in Kansas City and has appeared on the Day 1 radio program. He is part of the leadership team of the Institute of Preaching in Florida and has worked with the Episcopal Preaching Foundation’s Preaching Excellence Program. Attending a youth conference at Lake Junaluska as a teenager in 1990 played a central role in his eventual call to ministry, and it continues to be an honor to speak in Stuart Auditorium. He was the Preacher in Residence at Lake Junaluska in 2023, and the preacher for the Music and Worship Arts Week in 2019. He and his two daughters enjoy live musical theater, Marvel movies, and cheering on the Tampa Bay Rays.

Rev. Ann Haywood-Baxter, WNCC Clergy, Chaplain at Boston Children's Hospital

Celebration of Life Memorial Service, Saturday, June 22, 2024 at 11am

Rev. Ann G. Haywood-Baxter is an elder of the Western North Carolina Conference appointed to Boston Children's Hospital. She is an Endorsed United Methodist chaplain and is board certified with the Association of Professional Chaplains. She is a past president of the Pediatric Chaplains Network. Ann grew up on the Eastern Shore of Maryland and is a graduate of Wake Forest University. As a college student she was active in the Wesley Foundation Methodist campus ministry and is grateful for the ways campus ministry offered her opportunities for faith formation, service and fellowship. She served in the US Peace Corps in the island nation of Palau, and then returned to Winston-Salem and worked for a year at Forbush Elementary School. During this time she was active in the ministries of Mt. Tabor UMC and discerned a call to ordained ministry. Ann is a graduate of Duke Divinity School and completed Clinical Pastoral Education (CPE) at Duke Hospital. In 2003 she was appointed as Pediatric Chaplain to Massachusetts General Hospital. In 2012 she joined the Spiritual Care Department at Boston Children’s Hospital where she serves on a multi-faith team of chaplains who offer spiritual care to children of all ages, their families, and the hospital staff. She serves on the hospital’s Diversity, Equity and Inclusion Council and is member of the LGBTQ+ Allyship Group. Ann has training as a Spiritual Director and she is a Godly Play practitioner. She and her family are active in the ministries of Harvard-Epworth UMC in Cambridge, Massachusetts. Ann is an avid gardener, a Girl Scout volunteer, and a hiker. She is a member of the Brotherhood/Sisterhood of WNCC.

Rev. Ashley Crowder Stanley, Senior Pastor at Wellspring Congregation: An Inclusive UMC

Recognition of Retiring Clergy, Friday, June 21, 2024 at 4:30pm

Rev. Ashley Crowder Stanley is an ordained elder in the WNCC and currently serves as pastor at Wellspring Congregation: An Inclusive UMC in Asheville, NC. A graduate of Duke University and Duke Divinity School, she is a devoted fan and alumni of the “dark blue school.” Ordained in the Minnesota Annual Conference, Ashley began her ministry at Golden Valley UMC in a suburb of Minneapolis. Additionally, she was a hospital chaplain at Duke Hospital, at the University of Minnesota Hospital and Abbot-Northwestern Hospital, completing two and a half years of CPE. When she returned to the WNCC, she became an adjunct faculty member at Duke Divinity School where she taught for 8 years in the field of Pastoral Care and Counseling. She has served other wonderful churches in the WNCC including Biltmore, Wesley Memorial in High Point, and Mills River. She was also privileged to direct the Transition into Ministry Program in our conference, a ministry program for new clergy funded by the Lily Endowment. She has also been a District Superintendent.

Throughout her ministry, Ashley has served our conference and the wider denomination through service as Chair of the Board of Ordained Ministry, as member of several restructuring Task Forces, as a 4-time delegate to General Conference, as a 12-year member of the Duke University Board of Trustees, as a RIOM leaders, as the President of the Duke Divinity School National Alumni Association and a member of its Board of Visitors.

Ashley’s ministry passions are preaching and worship, community building and social justice work and making “good trouble.” As co-founder of Asheville’s Room in the Inn ministry for unhoused women, Ashley gives thanks for the many ongoing opportunities for ministry that living in the world offers.

She loves music, reading, playing the piano, writing prose, listening to birdsong, observing the wonder of children and being in community. Ashley and her husband, T.'s family includes their 3 adult children, their spouses, 6 grandchildren and a dog named Cooper. Her life has been immeasurably blessed by growing up in a pastor’s family, spending childhood summers at Lake Junaluska, having loving friends and family and being a member of this great Annual Conference.

Rev. Tammy Ingram, Senior Pastor of Bass Chapel UMC and Raleigh's Crossroads UMC

Recognition of Retiring Clergy, Friday, June 21, 2024 at 4:30pm

Pastor Tamara “Tammy” Ingram is a native of Greensboro, NC. She graduated from the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill with a degree in Economics and continued her education at Hood Theological Seminary in Salisbury, NC where she graduated with a Master’s Degree in Divinity.

Professionally, Rev. Tammy has over 33 years of management and corporate training experience; she worked for Aetna Insurance in its Greensboro, NC and High Point, NC locations and served as the company’s local Volunteer and Outreach Coordinator and its Southeast Regional Spokesperson.

Pastor Tammy answered the call to pastoral ministry in 2014. She currently serves as pastor of Raleigh’s Crossroads and Bass Chapel United Methodist churches in Greensboro NC. She will be ordained as an elder in full connection at the 2024 Western North Carolina Annual Conference and she is elated to use her ministerial gifts to proclaim the Word of God to inspire her audiences to become faithful, fruitful disciples for Jesus Christ.

Additionally, she was recently appointed as the Convener of the Religion and Race within the Western North Carolina Conference of the United Methodist Church. She is a servant of the Lord, and she is dedicated to representing Jesus Christ to the fullest, all-day, and everyday-- readily serving God and the people of God.

She is not ashamed of the gospel of Jesus Christ because she knows that it is the power of God unto salvation to everyone that believes it.

Pastor Tammy is married to Rev. Rodvegas Ingram. They are the proud parents of 2 sons Marc (Charity) and Cameron. Their latest and proudest titles are that of MiMi and Paw Paw to their 3 granddaughters: 9 year old Katelyn, 5 year old Carmen and 3 year old Charlie.

Pastor Tammy’s favorite scripture comes from the gospel of Saint Luke 4:18-19

“The Spirit of the LORD is upon Me, because He has anointed Me to preach the gospel to the poor; He has sent Me to heal the brokenhearted, to proclaim liberty to the captives, and recovery of sight to the blind, to set at liberty those who are oppressed: To proclaim the acceptable year of the LORD.”

Rev. Katey Galyon, Pastor of Discipleship at Christ UMC Greensboro

Recognition of Retiring Clergy, Friday, June 21, 2024 at 4:30pm

Katey Galyon is a lifelong United Methodist from Greensboro, North Carolina. She began her career as an Elementary School Teacher. During that time she felt the call to ministry while volunteering as a Youth Group Leader on the weekends. She began as a Youth Director at Christ United Methodist Church in Greensboro in 2015 and began the Candidacy Process and her Masters in Christian Practice through Duke Divinity School in 2016. She completed her degree in 2018 and will be ordained in full connection this June. Katey’s ministry at Christ Church over the last 9 years has led her from youth to children to adult discipleship ministry and now she will add missions this Summer while continuing to work in discipleship for all ages.

Katey married J.D. in October, 2018 and they share a very spoiled, 6 year old, border collie/lab mix named Gertey. Katey enjoys reading, crocheting, and walks with Gertey in her free time.
